Comments_List: By taking this course, I had a weekly reminder to put everything into perspective. A reminder to sit down and think about what really matters in life and in our existence. The readings for each week were fascinating and provided me with delicious food for thought and profound insight.
Insight into myself, really. Insight into how to bridge the gap between different religions.
We gained fundamental knowledge about Buddhism and considered its intersection between atheism and theism.
I learned about Buddhist ideas, atheist beliefs, and the questions religions aim to address. I
History and introduction to Buddhism, consideration of the plausibility behind enlightenment and reincarnation, exploration of atheist arguments, mindfulness and meditation practices.

Through this course I developed a broader understanding of a variety of religious and philosophical traditions, as well as a better understanding of my own thoughts and opinions regarding religion, spirituality, morality, and a number of other topics.

The course led us to reflect on the assumptions underlying our beliefs (whether a religious conviction or a form of knowledge). What began earlier in the semester as discrete moments of epistemic interrogation coalesced later into a new framework for asking the big questions in lifea framework which challenges the nature of assumptions in the first place. 

In this way, the course introduced and contextualized Buddhism outside Western and Judeo-Christian classifications and categories. Rather than a creed or ideology, Buddhism is presented as a commitment to a certain kind of awareness, transforming how I look at the world and my place in it. 

Overall, the course forced me to think critically about how we gain insights from the same data (i.e. the same phenomenological markers that make up our existence), and how we might develop from those insights an ethic of being and acting in the world.

I improved my writing, critical thinking, and discussion skills through weekly intellectual journal entries and discussions (including leading one) as well as the two papers. I also spent a lot of time introspecting about religion, purpose, atheism, Buddhism and how it all fits together.

I was surprised the seminar went so well with so many students. Professor Kim handled the organization well and delivered lectures of appropriate lengths.

The class had really interesting topics of discussion. I found professor Kim to give great lectures and really force us to grapple with hard questions in life. The curriculum and readings were very engaging. However, I think the student presentations could be made a little more brief. 15 mins was probably enough for us to discuss the main questions of the readings. The class was also too large for a seminar. Next time there should either be two sections, or enrollment should be capped. This felt like a lecture at times, which wasn't the intended format of the class.

Reflecting back on the course, I felt many of the small details that Professor Kim implemented greatly contributed to student engagement. For example, he had two students lead discussion each week with a presentation, brought in guest speakers for us to question and told some pretty crazy stories about his life! These might not seem like a big deal, but they really did add a lot of flavor to a long seminar period each Monday afternoon.

A great strength of the course is the positive, lively classroom environment Professor Kim facilitates, where different perspectives and questions are welcomed. 

The guest lectures were also insightful and illuminating, especially Stephen Batchelors. 

Perhaps the weakness of the course are the moments where we branch of into small groups during student-led discussions. The discussions were strongest when kept to a big round-table.

Strengths:
- Professor Kim clearly cares a lot about his students
- I found the material both interesting and personally relevant
- The course was very well organized and it was clear what was due when

Weaknesses:
- We often ran out of time and had to rush at the end of class
- At some points, the material felt a little repetitive

I LOVED this class (speaking as someone who dreaded having to take a second Hu!). It was interesting, made me introspect, and was not a lot of work (weekly journal entries aka reading responses, two 8-page papers and leading one class discussion). Professor Kim really cares about engaging his students so he's very available to meet outside of class, read over drafts, etc. While officially, topics were given for the midterm and final papers, he gave us a lot of flexibility - some people chose their own topics, some decided to write one 15-page paper instead, and some even decided to do alternate project forms (e.g. a documentary, artwork). Plus, he says outright that grading is not something that you need to worry about as long as you are engaged.
An amazing class, helps put into perspective many relevant questions on humanity, religion, faith, morality, meditation, and enlightenment.
